an5.106:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kosambiyaṃ viharati ghositārāme.
an5.106:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kosambī, in Ghosita’s Monastery.

an5.106:1.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an5.106:1.2.eng: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,

an5.106:2.1.pli: “Kittāvatā nu kho, bhante, bhikkhu saṅghe viharanto phāsuṃ vihareyyā”ti?
an5.106:2.1.eng: “Sir, how could a mendicant live comfortably while staying in a monastic community?”

an5.106:2.2.pli: “Yato kho, ānanda, bhikkhu attanā sīlasampanno hoti, no paraṃ adhisīle sampavattā;
an5.106:2.2.eng: “It’s when a mendicant is accomplished in their own ethical conduct, but they don’t urge others to be ethical.

an5.106:2.3.pli: ettāvatāpi kho, ānanda, bhikkhu saṅghe viharanto phāsuṃ vihareyyā”ti.
an5.106:2.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant could live comfortably while staying in a monastic community.”

an5.106:3.1.pli: “Siyā pana, bhante, aññopi pariyāyo yathā bhikkhu saṅghe viharanto phāsuṃ vihareyyā”ti?
an5.106:3.1.eng: “But sir, could there be another way for a mendicant to live comfortably while staying in a monastic community?”

an5.106:3.3.pli: Yato kho, ānanda, bhikkhu attanā sīlasampanno hoti, no paraṃ adhisīle sampavattā;
an5.106:3.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant is accomplished in their own ethical conduct, but they don’t urge others to be ethical.

an5.106:3.4.eng: And they watch themselves, but don’t watch others.

an5.106:3.5.pli: ettāvatāpi kho, ānanda, bhikkhu saṅghe viharanto phāsuṃ vihareyyā”ti.
an5.106:3.5.eng: That’s how a mendicant could live comfortably while staying in a monastic community.”

an5.106:4.1.pli: “Siyā pana, bhante, aññopi pariyāyo yathā bhikkhu saṅghe viharanto phāsuṃ vihareyyā”ti?
an5.106:4.1.eng: “But sir, could there be another way for a mendicant to live comfortably while staying in a monastic community?”

an5.106:4.3.pli: Yato kho, ānanda, bhikkhu attanā sīlasampanno hoti, no paraṃ adhisīle sampavattā;
an5.106:4.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant is accomplished in their own ethical conduct, but they don’t urge others to be ethical.

an5.106:4.4.eng: And they watch themselves, but don’t watch others.

an5.106:4.5.pli: apaññāto ca hoti, tena ca apaññātakena no paritassati;
an5.106:4.5.eng: And they’re not well-known, but aren’t bothered by that.

an5.106:4.6.pli: ettāvatāpi kho, ānanda, bhikkhu saṅghe viharanto phāsuṃ vihareyyā”ti.
an5.106:4.6.eng: That’s how a mendicant could live comfortably while staying in a monastic community.”

an5.106:5.1.pli: “Siyā pana, bhante, aññopi pariyāyo yathā bhikkhu saṅghe viharanto phāsuṃ vihareyyā”ti?
an5.106:5.1.eng: “But sir, could there be another way for a mendicant to live comfortably while staying in a monastic community?”

an5.106:5.3.pli: Yato kho, ānanda, bhikkhu attanā sīlasampanno hoti, no paraṃ adhisīle sampavattā;
an5.106:5.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant is accomplished in their own ethical conduct, but they don’t urge others to be ethical.

an5.106:5.4.eng: And they watch themselves, but don’t watch others.

an5.106:5.5.pli: apaññāto ca hoti, tena ca apaññātakena no paritassati;
an5.106:5.5.eng: And they’re not well-known, but aren’t bothered by that.

an5.106:5.6.pli: catunnañca jhānānaṃ ābhicetasikānaṃ diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārānaṃ nikāmalābhī hoti akicchalābhī akasiralābhī;
an5.106:5.6.eng: And they get the four absorptions—blissful meditations in this life that belong to the higher mind—when they want, without trouble or difficulty.

an5.106:5.7.pli: ettāvatāpi kho, ānanda, bhikkhu saṅghe viharanto phāsuṃ vihareyyā”ti.
an5.106:5.7.eng: That’s how a mendicant could live comfortably while staying in a monastic community.”

an5.106:6.1.pli: “Siyā pana, bhante, aññopi pariyāyo yathā bhikkhu saṅghe viharanto phāsuṃ vihareyyā”ti?
an5.106:6.1.eng: “But sir, might there be another way for a mendicant to live comfortably while staying in a monastic community?”

an5.106:6.3.pli: Yato kho, ānanda, bhikkhu attanā sīlasampanno hoti, no paraṃ adhisīle sampavattā;
an5.106:6.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant is accomplished in their own ethical conduct, but they don’t urge others to be ethical.

an5.106:6.4.eng: And they watch themselves, but don’t watch others.

an5.106:6.5.pli: apaññāto ca hoti, tena ca apaññātakena no paritassati;
an5.106:6.5.eng: And they’re not well-known, but aren’t bothered by that.

an5.106:6.6.pli: catunnañca jhānānaṃ ābhicetasikānaṃ diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārānaṃ nikāmalābhī hoti akicchalābhī akasiralābhī;
an5.106:6.6.eng: And they get the four absorptions—blissful meditations in this life that belong to the higher mind—when they want, without trouble or difficulty.

an5.106:6.7.pli: āsavānañca khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati;
an5.106:6.7.eng: And they realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.

an5.106:6.8.pli: ettāvatāpi kho, ānanda, bhikkhu saṅghe viharanto phāsuṃ vihareyya.
an5.106:6.8.eng: That’s how a mendicant could live comfortably while staying in a monastic community.

an5.106:7.1.pli: Imamhā cāhaṃ, ānanda, phāsuvihārā añño phāsuvihāro uttaritaro vā paṇītataro vā natthīti vadāmī”ti.
an5.106:7.1.eng: And I say that there is no better or finer way of living comfortably than this.”

an5.107:1.1.pli: “Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu āhuneyyo hoti pāhuneyyo dakkhiṇeyyo añjalikaraṇīyo anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassa.
an5.107:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a mendicant with five qualities is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of veneration with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.

an5.107:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlasampanno hoti, samādhisampanno hoti, paññāsampanno hoti, vimuttisampanno hoti, vimuttiñāṇadassanasampanno hoti.
an5.107:2.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant is accomplished in ethics, immersion, wisdom, freedom, and the knowledge and vision of freedom.

an5.107:3.1.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu āhuneyyo hoti pāhuneyyo dakkhiṇeyyo añjalikaraṇīyo anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassā”ti.
an5.107:3.1.eng: A mendicant with these five qualities is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of veneration with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.”

an5.108:1.1.pli: “Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu āhuneyyo hoti pāhuneyyo dakkhiṇeyyo …pe… anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassa.
an5.108:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a mendicant with five qualities is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of veneration with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.

an5.108:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu asekhena sīlakkhandhena samannāgato hoti, asekhena samādhikkhandhena samannāgato hoti, asekhena paññākkhandhena samannāgato hoti, asekhena vimuttikkhandhena samannāgato hoti, asekhena vimuttiñāṇadassanakkhandhena samannāgato hoti.
an5.108:2.2.eng: It’s when they have the entire spectrum of the adept’s ethics, immersion, wisdom, freedom, and knowledge and vision of freedom.

an5.108:2.3.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu āhuneyyo hoti …pe… anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassā”ti.
an5.108:2.3.eng: A mendicant with these five qualities … is the supreme field of merit for the world.”

an5.109:1.1.pli: “Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu cātuddiso hoti.
an5.109:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a mendicant with five qualities is at ease in any quarter.

an5.109:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlavā hoti, pātimokkhasaṃvarasaṃvuto viharati ācāragocarasampanno aṇumattesu vajjesu bhayadassāvī, samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu;
an5.109:1.3.eng: It’s when mendicant is ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and resorting for alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.

an5.109:1.4.pli: bahussuto hoti sutadharo sutasannicayo, ye te dhammā ādikalyāṇā majjhekalyāṇā pariyosānakalyāṇā sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ abhivadanti, tathārūpāssa dhammā bahussutā honti dhātā vacasā paricitā manasānupekkhitā diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhā;
an5.109:1.4.eng: They’re very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned. These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, rehearsing them, mentally scrutinizing them, and penetrating them theoretically.

an5.109:1.5.eng: They’re content with any kind of robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.

an5.109:1.6.pli: catunnaṃ jhānānaṃ ābhicetasikānaṃ diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārānaṃ nikāmalābhī hoti akicchalābhī akasiralābhī;
an5.109:1.6.eng: They get the four absorptions—blissful meditations in this life that belong to the higher mind—when they want, without trouble or difficulty.

an5.109:1.7.pli: āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
an5.109:1.7.eng: They realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.

an5.109:1.8.pli: Imehi, kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu cātuddiso hotī”ti.
an5.109:1.8.eng: A mendicant with these five qualities is at ease in any quarter.”

an5.11:1.1.eng: “I claim to have attained perfection and consummation of insight regarding principles not learned before from another.

an5.11:1.2.pli: Pañcimāni, bhikkhave, tathāgatassa tathāgatabalāni, yehi balehi samannāgato tathāgato āsabhaṃ ṭhānaṃ paṭijānāti, parisāsu sīhanādaṃ nadati, brahmacakkaṃ pavatteti.
an5.11:1.2.eng: The Realized One has five powers of a Realized One. With these he claims the bull’s place, roars his lion’s roar in the assemblies, and turns the divine wheel.

an5.11:1.4.eng: The powers of faith, conscience, prudence, energy, and wisdom.

an5.11:1.5.pli: imāni kho, bhikkhave, pañca tathāgatassa tathāgatabalāni yehi balehi samannāgato tathāgato āsabhaṃ ṭhānaṃ paṭijānāti, parisāsu sīhanādaṃ nadati, brahmacakkaṃ pavattetī”ti.
an5.11:1.5.eng: These are the five powers of a Realized One. With these he claims the bull’s place, roars his lion’s roar in the assemblies, and turns the divine wheel.”

an5.110:1.1.pli: “Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu alaṃ araññavanapatthāni pantāni senāsanāni paṭisevituṃ.
an5.110:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when a mendicant has five qualities they’re ready to frequent remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest.

an5.110:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlavā hoti …pe… samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu;
an5.110:1.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant is ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and resorting for alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.

an5.110:1.4.eng: They’re very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned. These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s totally full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, reciting them, mentally scrutinizing them, and penetrating them theoretically.

an5.110:1.5.pli: āraddhavīriyo viharati thāmavā daḷhaparakkamo anikkhittadhuro kusalesu dhammesu;
an5.110:1.5.eng: They live with energy roused up. They’re strong, staunchly vigorous, not slacking off when it comes to developing skillful qualities.

an5.110:1.6.pli: catunnaṃ jhānānaṃ ābhicetasikānaṃ diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārānaṃ nikāmalābhī hoti akicchalābhī akasiralābhī;
an5.110:1.6.eng: They get the four absorptions—blissful meditations in this life that belong to the higher mind—when they want, without trouble or difficulty.

an5.110:1.7.pli: āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
an5.110:1.7.eng: They realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.

an5.110:1.8.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu alaṃ araññavanapatthāni pantāni senāsanāni paṭisevitun”ti.
an5.110:1.8.eng: When a mendicant possesses these five qualities they’re ready to frequent remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest.”

an5.111:1.1.pli: “Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato kulūpako bhikkhu kulesu appiyo ca hoti amanāpo ca agaru ca abhāvanīyo ca.
an5.111:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a mendicant with five qualities who visits families is unlikable and disagreeable, not respected or admired.

an5.111:1.3.pli: Asanthavavissāsī ca hoti, anissaravikappī ca, vissaṭṭhupasevī ca, upakaṇṇakajappī ca, atiyācanako ca.
an5.111:1.3.eng: They act as though they’re close to people they hardly know. They give away things they don’t own. They over-associate with close friends. They whisper in the ear. And they ask for too much.

an5.111:1.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato kulūpako bhikkhu kulesu appiyo ca hoti amanāpo ca agaru ca abhāvanīyo ca.
an5.111:1.4.eng: A mendicant with these five qualities who visits families is unlikable and disagreeable, not respected or admired.

an5.111:2.1.pli: Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato kulūpako bhikkhu kulesu piyo ca hoti manāpo ca garu ca bhāvanīyo ca.
an5.111:2.1.eng: A mendicant with five qualities who visits families is dear and beloved, respected and admired.

an5.111:2.3.pli: Na asanthavavissāsī ca hoti, na anissaravikappī ca, na vissaṭṭhupasevī ca, na upakaṇṇakajappī ca, na atiyācanako ca.
an5.111:2.3.eng: They don’t act as though they’re close to people they hardly know. They don’t give away things they don’t own. They don’t over-associate with close friends. They don’t whisper in the ear. And they don’t ask for too much.

an5.111:2.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato kulūpako bhikkhu kulesu piyo ca hoti manāpo ca garu ca bhāvanīyo cā”ti.
an5.111:2.4.eng: A mendicant with these five qualities who visits families is dear and beloved, respected and admired.”

an5.112:1.1.pli: “Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato pacchāsamaṇo na ādātabbo.
an5.112:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, you shouldn’t take a second monk with five qualities.

an5.112:1.3.pli: Atidūre vā gacchati accāsanne vā, na pattapariyāpannaṃ gaṇhati, āpattisāmantā bhaṇamānaṃ na nivāreti, bhaṇamānassa antarantarā kathaṃ opāteti, duppañño hoti jaḷo eḷamūgo.
an5.112:1.3.eng: They walk too far away or too close behind. They don’t take your bowl when it’s full. They don’t warn you when your speech is bordering on an offense. They keep on interrupting while you’re speaking. And they’re witless, dull, and idiotic.

an5.112:1.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato pacchāsamaṇo na ādātabbo.
an5.112:1.4.eng: You shouldn’t take a second monk these five qualities.

an5.112:2.1.pli: Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato pacchāsamaṇo ādātabbo.
an5.112:2.1.eng: You should take a second monk with five qualities.

an5.112:2.3.pli: Nātidūre gacchati na accāsanne, pattapariyāpannaṃ gaṇhati, āpattisāmantā bhaṇamānaṃ nivāreti, bhaṇamānassa na antarantarā kathaṃ opāteti, paññavā hoti ajaḷo aneḷamūgo.
an5.112:2.3.eng: They don’t walk too far away or too close behind. They take your bowl when it is full. They warn you when your speech is bordering on an offense. They don’t interrupt while you’re speaking. And they’re wise, bright, and clever.

an5.112:2.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato pacchāsamaṇo ādātabbo”ti.
an5.112:2.4.eng: You should take a second monk with these five qualities.”

an5.113:1.1.pli: “Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu abhabbo sammāsamādhiṃ upasampajja viharituṃ.
an5.113:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a mendicant who has five qualities can’t enter and remain in right immersion.

an5.113:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu akkhamo hoti rūpānaṃ, akkhamo saddānaṃ, akkhamo gandhānaṃ, akkhamo rasānaṃ, akkhamo phoṭṭhabbānaṃ.
an5.113:1.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant can’t endure sights, sounds, smells, tastes, and touches.

an5.113:1.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu abhabbo sammāsamādhiṃ upasampajja viharituṃ.
an5.113:1.4.eng: A mendicant who possesses these five qualities can’t enter and remain in right immersion.

an5.113:2.1.pli: Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu bhabbo sammāsamādhiṃ upasampajja viharituṃ.
an5.113:2.1.eng: A mendicant who has five qualities can enter and remain in right immersion.

an5.113:2.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu khamo hoti rūpānaṃ, khamo saddānaṃ, khamo gandhānaṃ, khamo rasānaṃ, khamo phoṭṭhabbānaṃ.
an5.113:2.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant can endure sights, sounds, smells, tastes, and touches.

an5.113:2.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu bhabbo sammāsamādhiṃ upasampajja viharitun”ti.
an5.113:2.4.eng: A mendicant who possesses these five qualities can enter and remain in right immersion.”

an5.114:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā magadhesu viharati andhakavinde.
an5.114:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Magadhans at Andhakavinda.

an5.114:1.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
an5.114:1.2.eng: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him:

an5.114:2.1.pli: “Ye te, ānanda, bhikkhū navā acirapabbajitā adhunāgatā imaṃ dhammavinayaṃ, te vo, ānanda, bhikkhū pañcasu dhammesu samādapetabbā nivesetabbā patiṭṭhāpetabbā.
an5.114:2.1.eng: “Ānanda, those mendicants who are junior, recently gone forth, newly come to this teaching and training should be encouraged, supported, and established in five things.

an5.114:2.3.pli: ‘Etha tumhe, āvuso, sīlavā hotha, pātimokkhasaṃvarasaṃvutā viharatha ācāragocarasampannā aṇumattesu vajjesu bhayadassāvino, samādāya sikkhatha sikkhāpadesū’ti—iti pātimokkhasaṃvare samādapetabbā nivesetabbā patiṭṭhāpetabbā.
an5.114:2.3.eng: They should be encouraged, supported, and established in restraint in the monastic code: ‘Reverends, please be ethical. Live restrained in the monastic code, conducting yourselves well and resorting for alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, keep the rules you’ve undertaken.’

an5.114:3.1.pli: ‘Etha tumhe, āvuso, indriyesu guttadvārā viharatha ārakkhasatino nipakkasatino, sārakkhitamānasā satārakkhena cetasā samannāgatā’ti—iti indriyasaṃvare samādapetabbā nivesetabbā patiṭṭhāpetabbā.
an5.114:3.1.eng: They should be encouraged, supported, and established in sense restraint: ‘Reverends, please live with sense doors guarded, mindfully alert and on guard, with protected mind, having a heart protected by mindfulness.’

an5.114:4.1.pli: ‘Etha tumhe, āvuso, appabhassā hotha, bhasse pariyantakārino’ti—iti bhassapariyante samādapetabbā nivesetabbā patiṭṭhāpetabbā.
an5.114:4.1.eng: They should be encouraged, supported, and established in limiting their speech: ‘Reverends, please speak little. Put a limit on your speech.’

an5.114:5.1.pli: ‘Etha tumhe, āvuso, āraññikā hotha, araññavanapatthāni pantāni senāsanāni paṭisevathā’ti—iti kāyavūpakāse samādapetabbā nivesetabbā patiṭṭhāpetabbā.
an5.114:5.1.eng: They should be encouraged, supported, and established in retreat: ‘Reverends, please live in the wilderness. Frequent remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest.’

an5.114:6.1.pli: ‘Etha tumhe, āvuso, sammādiṭṭhikā hotha sammādassanena samannāgatā’ti—iti sammādassane samādapetabbā nivesetabbā patiṭṭhāpetabbā.
an5.114:6.1.eng: They should be encouraged, supported, and established in right perspective: ‘Reverends, please hold right view and have right perspective.’

an5.114:6.2.pli: Ye te, ānanda, bhikkhū navā acirapabbajitā adhunāgatā imaṃ dhammavinayaṃ, te vo, ānanda, bhikkhū imesu pañcasu dhammesu samādapetabbā nivesetabbā patiṭṭhāpetabbā”ti.
an5.114:6.2.eng: Those mendicants who are junior, recently gone forth, newly come to this teaching and training should be encouraged, supported, and established in these five things.”

an5.115:1.1.pli: “Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgatā bhikkhunī yathābhataṃ nikkhittā evaṃ niraye.
an5.115:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a nun with five qualities is cast down to hell.

an5.115:1.3.pli: Āvāsamaccharinī hoti, kulamaccharinī hoti, lābhamaccharinī hoti, vaṇṇamaccharinī hoti, dhammamaccharinī hoti.
an5.115:1.3.eng: She is stingy with dwellings, families, material things, praise, and the teaching.

an5.115:1.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgatā bhikkhunī yathābhataṃ nikkhittā evaṃ niraye.
an5.115:1.4.eng: A nun with these five qualities is cast down to hell.

an5.115:2.1.pli: Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgatā bhikkhunī yathābhataṃ nikkhittā evaṃ sagge.
an5.115:2.1.eng: A nun with five qualities is raised up to heaven.

an5.115:2.3.pli: Na āvāsamaccharinī hoti, na kulamaccharinī hoti, na lābhamaccharinī hoti, na vaṇṇamaccharinī hoti, na dhammamaccharinī hoti.
an5.115:2.3.eng: She is not stingy with dwellings, families, material things, praise, or the teaching.

an5.115:2.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgatā bhikkhunī yathābhataṃ nikkhittā evaṃ sagge”ti.
an5.115:2.4.eng: A nun with these five qualities is raised up to heaven.”

an5.116:1.1.pli: “Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgatā bhikkhunī yathābhataṃ nikkhittā evaṃ niraye.
an5.116:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a nun with five qualities is cast down to hell.

an5.116:1.3.eng: Without examining or scrutinizing, she praises those deserving of criticism,

an5.116:1.4.eng: and criticizes those deserving of praise.

an5.116:1.5.pli: ananuvicca apariyogāhetvā appasādanīye ṭhāne pasādaṃ upadaṃseti,
an5.116:1.5.eng: She arouses faith in things that are dubious,

an5.116:1.6.pli: ananuvicca apariyogāhetvā pasādanīye ṭhāne appasādaṃ upadaṃseti,
an5.116:1.6.eng: and doesn’t arouse faith in things that are inspiring.

an5.116:1.7.eng: And she wastes gifts given in faith.

an5.116:1.8.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgatā bhikkhunī yathābhataṃ nikkhittā evaṃ niraye.
an5.116:1.8.eng: A nun with these five qualities is cast down to hell.

an5.116:2.1.pli: Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgatā bhikkhunī yathābhataṃ nikkhittā evaṃ sagge.
an5.116:2.1.eng: A nun with five qualities is raised up to heaven.

an5.116:2.3.eng: After examining and scrutinizing, she criticizes those deserving of criticism,

an5.116:2.4.eng: and praises those deserving of praise.

an5.116:2.5.pli: anuvicca pariyogāhetvā appasādanīye ṭhāne appasādaṃ upadaṃseti,
an5.116:2.5.eng: She doesn’t arouse faith in things that are dubious,

an5.116:2.6.pli: anuvicca pariyogāhetvā pasādanīye ṭhāne pasādaṃ upadaṃseti,
an5.116:2.6.eng: and does arouse faith in things that are inspiring.

an5.116:2.7.eng: And she doesn’t waste gifts given in faith.

an5.116:2.8.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgatā bhikkhunī yathābhataṃ nikkhittā evaṃ sagge”ti.
an5.116:2.8.eng: A nun with these five qualities is raised up to heaven.”

an5.117:2.8.eng: A nun with these five qualities is raised up to heaven.”

an5.119:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a nun with five qualities is cast down to hell.

an5.119:1.3.eng: Without examining or scrutinizing, she praises those deserving of criticism,

an5.119:1.4.eng: and criticizes those deserving of praise.

an5.119:1.7.eng: and wastes gifts given in faith.

an5.119:2.1.pli: Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgatā bhikkhunī yathābhataṃ nikkhittā evaṃ sagge.
an5.119:2.1.eng: A nun with five qualities is raised up to heaven.

an5.119:2.4.eng: and praises those deserving of praise.

an5.119:2.8.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgatā bhikkhunī yathābhataṃ nikkhittā evaṃ sagge”ti.
an5.119:2.8.eng: A nun with these five qualities is raised up to heaven.”

an5.12:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these five powers of a trainee.

an5.12:1.3.eng: The powers of faith, conscience, prudence, energy, and wisdom.

an5.12:1.4.eng: These are the five powers of a trainee.

an5.12:1.5.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ sekhabalānaṃ etaṃ aggaṃ etaṃ saṅgāhikaṃ etaṃ saṅghātaniyaṃ, yadidaṃ paññābalaṃ.
an5.12:1.5.eng: Of these five powers of a trainee, the power of wisdom is the chief. It holds and binds everything together.

an5.12:2.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, kūṭāgārassa etaṃ aggaṃ etaṃ saṅgāhikaṃ etaṃ saṅghātaniyaṃ, yadidaṃ kūṭaṃ.
an5.12:2.1.eng: It’s like a bungalow. The roof-peak is the chief point, which holds and binds everything together.

an5.12:2.2.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, imesaṃ pañcannaṃ sekhabalānaṃ etaṃ aggaṃ etaṃ saṅgāhikaṃ etaṃ saṅghātaniyaṃ, yadidaṃ paññābalaṃ.
an5.12:2.2.eng: In the same way, of these five powers of a trainee, the power of wisdom is the chief. It holds and binds everything together.

an5.12:3.1.eng: So you should train like this:

an5.12:3.2.pli: ‘saddhābalena samannāgatā bhavissāma sekhabalena, hirībalena … ottappabalena … vīriyabalena … paññābalena samannāgatā bhavissāma sekhabalenā’ti.
an5.12:3.2.eng: ‘We will have the trainee’s powers of faith, conscience, prudence, energy, and wisdom.’
